intro: Loxophyllum racemosum, commonly known as the clustered leek, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its strap-like, grass-like leaves and clusters of white or pale pink flowers. The plant typically grows in wetlands and along stream banks, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. Its botanical features include a bulbous base and a short, stout stem that supports its foliage and floral display. Loxophyllum racemosum is often found in shaded to partially shaded environments, making it a notable species in wetland ecosystems.
